unnormalised: Okay, so, like, figuring out time zones in India can be a total head-scratcher, right? Especially when you're trying to coordinate stuff with people all over the place. I mean, we officially have only 1 time zone – Indian Standard Time (IST), which is GMT+5:30. But the sun definitely rises, like, way earlier in the East, near Guwahati, than it does in the West, near, say, Mumbai.
normalised: Okay, so, like, figuring out time zones in India can be a total head-scratcher, right? Especially when you're trying to coordinate stuff with people all over the place. I mean, we officially have only one time zone – Indian Standard Time (I-S-T), which is G-M-T plus five hours and thirty minutes. But the sun definitely rises, like, way earlier in the East, near Guwahati, than it does in the West, near, say, Mumbai.

unnormalised: It's kinda crazy to think that everyone from Arunachal Pradesh to Gujarat is operating on the same time. Imagine, folks in the Northeast are already having their morning chai while it's still pitch black in some parts of Rajasthan! Some tea gardens in Assam and WB actually used to follow "Tea Garden Time," which was half an hour ahead of IST! Talk about being ahead of the curve.
normalised: It's kinda crazy to think that everyone from Arunachal Pradesh to Gujarat is operating on the same time. Imagine, folks in the North-east are already having their morning chai while it's still pitch black in some parts of Rajasthan! Some tea gardens in Assam and W-B actually used to follow "Tea Garden Time," which was half an hour ahead of I-S-T! Talk about being ahead of the curve.

unnormalised: And then there's the whole daylight saving thing. We don't do it, officially. But back in the day, during the 1962 Sino-Indian War, the 1965 Indo-Pak war, and the 1971 Indo-Pak war, they used to advance the clock by an hour to save energy. It’s like we were experimenting to see if DST could work for us. The adjustment was apparently reverted each time, sometime after the end of the conflict.
normalised: And then there's the whole daylight saving thing. We don't do it, officially. But back in the day, during the nineteen sixty two Sino-Indian War, the nineteen sixty five Indo-Pak war, and the nineteen seventy one Indo-Pak war, they used to advance the clock by an hour to save energy. It’s like we were experimenting to see if D-S-T could work for us. The adjustment was apparently reverted each time, sometime after the end of the conflict.

unnormalised: Honestly, a lot of people, particularly in the North-eastern states, keep pushing for a separate time zone. Imagine setting up meetings with someone in, say, Itanagar, and having to mentally calculate the difference. It gets tiring! Plus, proponents claim a separate time zone would boost productivity and save electricity in the region.
normalised: Honestly, a lot of people, particularly in the North-eastern states, keep pushing for a separate time zone. Imagine setting up meetings with someone in, say, Itanagar, and having to mentally calculate the difference. It gets tiring! Plus, proponents claim a separate time zone would boost productivity and save electricity in the region.

unnormalised: But the government's always been a bit hesitant. They worry it’ll create confusion, especially for railways and communication networks. Plus, there’s the whole symbolic thing – keeping one time zone emphasizes unity or something. And according to this one report I read, the perceived power saving is estimated to only be 2.7 million kWh per annum.
normalised: But the government's always been a bit hesitant. They worry it’ll create confusion, especially for railways and communication networks. Plus, there’s the whole symbolic thing – keeping one time zone emphasizes unity or something. And according to this one report I read, the perceived power saving is estimated to only be two point seven million kilo watt hour per annum.

unnormalised: So, for now, we're stuck with one-size-fits-all IST. Next time you're arranging a call with someone in a different part of the country, remember that even though the clock says the same thing, their day might be starting or ending at a completely different pace! And if you see 'IST' listed, just remember that means you’re 5 hours & 30 mins ahead of GMT.
normalised: So, for now, we're stuck with one-size-fits-all I-S-T. Next time you're arranging a call with someone in a different part of the country, remember that even though the clock says the same thing, their day might be starting or ending at a completely different pace! And if you see 'I-S-T' listed, just remember that means you’re five hours and thirty minutes ahead of G-M-T.

unnormalised: Just something to think about while you're sipping your evening chai at 7 PM IST, knowing that someone else might already be tucked into bed! Cheers!
